messages.subject: Fw: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Sorry...I intended to make note that the illustrated Akasaka tsuba on p.34 (referred to earlier) does NOT have these kakushi-tagane. Ron STL ... From: Ron
messages.messageBody:
Sorry...I intended to make note that the illustrated Akasaka tsuba on p.34 (referred to earlier) does NOT have these kakushi-tagane.

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, April 18, 2005 11:45 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba


Hi Rich, all -

Not to be a wet blanket here but--referring to the first tsuba with chidori--I suspect this would be designated Tosa Myochin made in Akasaka style. I say this because of the distinctive tagane (kakushi-tagane) around the nakago-ana, a Tosa Myochin trait according the Sasano and others. (Sasano points this out in his original English sukashi tsuba book, pages 218-220.)

Not to muddy up the waters, but an odd experience with a like-tsuba was experienced by me back in the early 1980s. In 1979 during a Chicago NTHK shinsa, Sasano papered a friend's mumei tsuba as (I believe) 2nd master Akasaka work. Later, the tsuba went to a Haynes auction where I purchased it. Bob Haynes was adamant about the tsuba "looking like" Akasaka, but that in reality it was Tosa Myochi. His argument was based largely on these "wisker-like" kakushi-tagane that were place around the tsuba's nakago-ana. I sold that tsuba a year or two ago and passed on this story along with the original NTHK paper declaring it Akasaka. Either way, it remains a fine tsuba!

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, April 17, 2005 6:54 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba


All, just thought I'd share my two latest purchases.

This first one is reported to be the 4th Akasaka Tadatoki. There is an
almost identical one in the
book ' Akasaka Tsuba ' on page 34. It could be one of his students work
I guess.

http://img167.auctions.yahoo.co.jp/users/7/4/5/7/fmm48822-img512x472-11123447020881-y-1.jpg

http://img167.auctions.yahoo.co.jp/users/7/4/5/7/fmm48822-img472x354-11123447260881-y-3.jpg

This next one, signed Bushu Jinun Akasaka Tadatoki - Seitetsu wo motte
kore wo kitaeru. ( "forged with refined (pure) iron." )
I think is the 6th Tadatoki ( my guess anyway ), maybe the 5th on a
scrape but the 7th is a possibility as well.

> http://img123.auctions.yahoo.co.jp/users/7/4/5/7/fmm48822-img591x512-11131288702197-y-1.jpg

http://img123.auctions.yahoo.co.jp/users/7/4/5/7/fmm48822-img591x512-11131288832197-y-2.jpg

any thought's or comments aprreciated.

Rich
